Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Use of Information and Communication Technologies in Violence Interruption

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although crime has decreased across most major US cities, violent crime is still a prominent issue in many urban environments. Neighborhoods that are plagued by such excessive violence endure negative effects on social and economic development. Though there are several approaches to addressing gun violence, one successful public health approach to reducing violence focuses on violence interruption, a neighborhood-level model whereby trained intervention workers identify potential violent events and provide immediate alternatives to disrupt violent incidents in their communities. This project investigates the potential of a mobile phone application to help intervention workers predict and interrupt violence during crimes and violent incidents. Violence interruption workers also provide long-term outreach in an attempt to permanently change violent behavior, including providing access to resources such as mental health services, social services, educational opportunities, and work training. This award will also support the design and development of a mobile application that uses predictive analytic techniques to provide violence interruption workers with the most effective intervention strategies based on data from over a decade of prior interventions.

Working with a leading violence interruption organization, this project examines how a mobile application can improve violence interruption outcomes by providing recommendations for the most effective strategies for resolving violent conflicts. The PI and her students will evaluate the mobile application in a 3-month deployment in Chicago during the summer, typically the most violent period of the year. In addition to supporting the reduction of violence, results from this project will lead to a deeper understanding of how to design technology to scale effective violence interruption techniques informed by public health principles. Furthermore, using computational analysis techniques to provide the most effective interruption techniques to violence interruption workers will not only advance our knowledge of the role of technology in violence interruption, but also extend prior literature pertaining to the social and behavioral impact of technology use in crime prevention and violence for those most affected by violent crime. This work will support improvements in the science of broadening participation, in that the focus will be on residents in low income, high crime neighborhoods and local, nonprofit organizations attempting to reduce and mitigate violence in their communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While crime has decreased across most major US cities, violent crime is still a prominent issue in many urban areas, impeding on the social and economic development of neighborhoods plagued by violence. While there have been several approaches to addressing gun violence (including increases in law enforcement, policy changes such as tougher sentencing and stricter gun laws, creating community-based programs that focus on youth job training and recidivism), the results of such approaches have been mixed, some even detrimental to the targeted communities.

As an alternative approach, organizations such as the Centers for Disease Control view violence as a public health issue. This perspective has led to the creation of a public health approach to violence prevention that focuses on 1) interrupting violent conflicts, 2) working with high-risk individuals to modify violent behavior, and 3) shifting community norms. Violence interruption is a neighborhood-level model, where trained violence prevention workers identify conflicts that have the potential to become violent and provide immediate alternatives to disrupt the cycle of violent incidents in their communities. After mediating the incident, interrupters collaborate with long-term outreach workers to permanently change the violent behavior of those involved in violence interruptions, including providing access to resources such as mental health services, social services, educational opportunities, and work training. This EAGER grant funded the design, development, and evaluation of a mobile application ('app') that supports violence interrupters when they are mediating violent conflict.

Building on a pilot study of interviews, a focus group of violence prevention workers, and a decade of experience by the PI of understanding and designing technologies that support community-driven engagement to address local crime and violence, the goals of the mobile application were 4-fold: (1) to improve conflict mediation outcomes by encouraging the use of a variety of conflict mediation strategies; (2) to provide easy access to conflict mediation training materials; (3) to support communication within and between violence prevention sites/organizations; and (4) to improve worker safety, particularly in the context of dangerous situations.

To achieve the goals, the app has 5 main features strategically designed to optimize conflict mediation and violence reduction outcomes:

(1)  Customized guidance: Interrupters have the ability to input five key conflict parameters (i.e., motivation for conflict, number of people involved, number of groups involved, presence of a weapon, if a gun was fired). The app then generates the most effective strategies in rank order based upon these parameters and outlines best practices for enacting the best strategy.

(2)  Training room: Interrupters can access refresher tutorials that prepare them not only for an immediate conflict, but also facilitate ongoing skill development and knowledge reinforcement.

(3)  Distress signal: The app enables on-the-spot assistance in situations that escalate into emergencies by sharing the location of the distressed worker, which triggers an immediate response from staff members, program managers, supervisors, and the implementing agency.

(4)  Peer learning: The app displays information regarding which sites have the highest success/experience rates with the generated strategies. This enables access to subject-matter expertise and builds peer-learning networks across violence prevention sites.

(5)  Connections: The app allows violence prevention workers to connect with other violence prevention workers using this private, secure network. In addition to posting public messages, violence prevention workers can send private messages to each other about current activities and interruption strategies.

To understand its impact, the Violence Interrupter phone app was deployed as a program enhancement technology in six (6) Chicago community areas for a total of three (3) months (April -- June 2018). A total of 56 violence prevention workers participated in the entire study. To evaluate the app, a triangulated research method was used, which consisted of pre and post surveys, case study interviews, and log data from the app usage.

While all users found the mobile app useful, findings suggest that the app met a need that other social media apps do not, largely due to the privacy it affords and its ability to create a community of violence prevention workers. Workers used the app to learn about events held by other sites and to share information and photos about their events. The social media feature also helped create a sense of unity by making and continuing to build relationships and connections across sites/organizations, thereby creating a city-wide community of violence prevention workers.

The results of this work have been (or are being) disseminated in academic venues (e.g., conferences, journals) as well as practitioner venues (e.g., presentations to various violence prevention organizations, social media companies). We have conducted professional development (PD) workshops for violence prevention workers, where they learned to use the app and talk more broadly about the role of technology in violence prevention. Outcomes including papers, presentations, posters, and training material will be made available at request.
